summary_points.title: Market Plunges on 50% US Tariffs
summary_points.summary: The Sensex crashed 849.37 points (1.04%) to close at 80,786.54 and the Nifty 50 fell 255.70 points (1.02%) to finish at 24,712.05 after the US imposed an additional 25% tariff, bringing the cumulative rate on Indian exports to 50%.

summary_points.title: Extended Two-Day Slide and Wealth Erosion
summary_points.summary: The Sensex and Nifty extended their declines for a second straight session, with the Sensex losing 706 points (0.87%) to settle at 80,080.57 and the Nifty down 211 points (0.85%) to 24,500.90, wiping out roughly ₹4 lakh crore in market capitalization in a single day.

summary_points.title: Sectoral Outlook: Export vs Domestic Demand
summary_points.summary: Analysts warn that export-oriented sectors are likely to remain under selling pressure on any uptick due to the new tariffs, while domestic demand-driven segments such as FMCG and consumer discretionary may offer relative stability. Key triggers to watch include foreign fund flows, global market trends, and any policy steps to cushion trade concerns.

summary_points.title: Tariffs Seen as Temporary Aberration
summary_points.summary: Despite the heavy sentiment impact of 50% US tariffs, strategists believe this measure is a short-term aberration that will be resolved diplomatically. Comments from the US Treasury secretary signalling eventual cooperation should help prevent a full-blown market panic.

summary_points.title: Global Cues and Gift Nifty Signal Weak Start
summary_points.summary: Asian markets were mixed—Tokyo’s Nikkei rose 0.20%, Hong Kong futures pointed lower—while the US S&P 500 hit an intraday record high. Meanwhile, Gift Nifty trading at a discount of around 66–82 points to Nifty futures suggests Indian markets are set for a negative opening.

summary_points.title: Technical Indicators Turn Bearish
summary_points.summary: On the charts, the Sensex formed a long bearish daily candle and a lower top on intraday patterns, reinforcing a negative bias and suggesting traders remain cautious amid the ongoing selloff.

top_performers.explanation: The Nifty Consumer Durables index was the only sector in the green (up 0.56%), driven by Titan’s 1.08% gain.
Hero MotoCorp and Maruti Suzuki both featured among the top gainers, underpinning a relative outperformance in autos.
Coal India’s 0.68% rise helped lift the energy/mining segment, making it one of the better-performing pockets of the market.

top_underperformers.explanation: Nifty Bank, along with PSU and private bank indices, suffered losses of more than 1% amid broad selling in the financial system.
Shriram Finance slid nearly 4%, dragging the broader Financial Services index down over 1%.
HCL Technologies and TCS each fell by around 3%, resulting in the Nifty IT index losing more than 1% on the day.

market_drivers.summary: Indian equity markets tumbled as Washington’s 25% tariffs on Indian exports triggered fresh selling, compounded by sluggish global cues, sustained foreign institutional outflows and rich valuations amid lacklustre corporate earnings. While a short‐lived uptick emerged after the government granted a cotton import duty exemption and investors eyed GST rationalisation measures—particularly in consumer durables ahead of the festive season—broader export‐oriented sectors like metals, realty and pharma remained under pressure, leaving defensive names in FMCG and consumer staples to offer relative stability.
